Aalto University Department of Computer Science Semantic Computing Research Group (SeCo) Email: eero.hyvonen(at)aalto.fi GSM +358 50 384 1618 Director (emer.) Helsinki Centre for Digital Humanities (HELDIG) University of Helsinki Faculty of Arts Finland Email: eero.hyvonen(at)helsinki.fi Adjunct Professor (Title of Docent) University of Helsinki Department of Computer Science Finland Email: eero.hyvonen(at)cs.helsinki.fi Faculty Affiliate Geneva Graduate Institute Center for Digital Humanities and Multilateralism Switzerland Address Aalto University Department of Computer Science P.O. Box 15500 FI-00076 Aalto Office: Computer Science Building, Konemiehentie 2, Room B346 Curriculum Vitae Eero Hyvönen is professor of computer science (focusing on semantic media technology) at the Aalto University, Department of Computer Science (emer.), director of Helsinki Centre for Digital Humanities (HELDIG) (emer.) at the University of Helsinki, and Faculty Affiliate at the Geneva Graduate Institute, Center for Digital Humanities and Multilateralism, Geneva, Switzerland. He directs the Semantic Computing Research Group (SeCo) specializing on Semantic Web technologies, Artifical Intelligence, and applications. A major recent theme (since 2001) in his research has been development of the national level semantic web infrastructure and its application in different areas. Eero Hyvönen has published over 600 research articles and books and has got over 30 awards and acknowledgements, such as the international Semantic Web Challenge Award (twice) (Japan, Germany), World Summit Award (WSA) by UNESCO (Dubai), LODLAM Open Data Prize (Italy), and State Award for Public Information (Tiedonjulkistamisen valtionpalkinto) and Prime Minister’s Innovation Award in Finland. He has acted in the editorial boards of Semantic Web - Interoperability, Usability, Applicability, Semantic Computing, International Journal of Metadata, Semantics, and Ontologies, and International Journal on Semantic Web and Information Systems, and has co-chaired and acted in the programme committees of tens of major conferences.
